@DanielYerger3 @fpassociation I can absolutely appreciate the frustration of a career changer coming in and trying to find community to support them and being limited from NexGen. But that's a not a failure or discrimination of NexGen, it's a failure of FPA to make the Career Changer group/resources needed.

@DanielYerger3 @fpassociation FPA tried to bolt career changers it into young advisors with Bridge The Gap in early 2000s. Tried again in late 2000s to compete against NexGen (still separate then). With mid-career advisors in early 2010s. Was there for them all. All not-CC-focused initiatives failed.

@DanielYerger3 @fpassociation Point just being - it's not a legal discrimination issue as far as we could find, based on how the lawyers themselves do it. 

Yes, moral/ethical/other dynamics are separate.

@DanielYerger3 @fpassociation Right, and all I'm saying is that your trajectory may have benefitted MORE with a community that fit you even more closely.

The point of the age limit wasn't to take anything away from those it your position. It was to give them MORE by providing an even tighter community.

@DanielYerger3 @fpassociation Doubt it will be an issue for the lawyers for Colorado-based FPA, since the Colorado Bar Association itself has a Young Lawyers Division that is limited to lawyers age 36 and under. https://t.co/LT14hUvmKB

The age threshold wasn't random. We did a little research at the time. ü§£

@FiSurgi @RetirementRisks Instead of being told "not saving now is NORMAL, don't beat yourself up, but let's talk about what you're going to do in 5-15 years when your income may double or more and you need to change your approach then to save effectively when you really finally can save a LOT"

@FiSurgi @RetirementRisks Right except the industry shellacks young people with guilt for not being able to save a bunch in their 20s when they literally can't. And by the time they're in their 30s and can, already feel like failures and might not because they've given up. üòî

@FiSurgi @RetirementRisks See https://t.co/8DSu3krLpe and also https://t.co/hJanT9O1mF for more.

Same pathway for a lot of young people who FIRE very early. They don't save early and often. They stabilize a modest standard of living, save EVERYTHING above that as income rises, hit 50%+ savings rates.

@FiSurgi @RetirementRisks More reflective of how income tends to actually grow in our 20s/30s. And important b/c it highlights how households can actually go from no savings to 20%/30%/50% savings rates as income rises. Whereas if you tell ppl to save 15% they do, and it's LESS in long run!

@FiSurgi @RetirementRisks Lifecycle finance framework has been around a long time. Quite sound, though the media is distorting it.

Better framing: "let's acknowledge that when you're young & can barely afford rent you won't save b/c you can't but when income rises you save a ton b/c then you really can"

@CarolynMcC @CPAPlanner Per the lifecycle finance paper at the beginning of this discussion - mathematically, most young people literally aren't financially able in their early years. That's WHY they end out with debt early on ("dis-saving" in the paper). Income-constrained reality.

@CarolynMcC @CPAPlanner I'm extremely cognizant of that. Talk about a version of it in our 'behavioral-finance' presentation too.

Key, as you note, is they have to be ready to participate in the change. I'd also add they have to be actually CAPABLE of it. Not always the case for young-person saving.

@CPAPlanner @CarolynMcC And rather than setting expectation "you can't save right now, but when your income lifts you can be saving 30% to 40% of your income" (which is quite economically feasible, & what the original paper highlights) we focus on miniscule savings in their 20s that build wrong habits.

@CPAPlanner @CarolynMcC Whether someone MATERIALLY increases their savings when their income doubles (from early 20s to late 30s) is not a function of whether they saved 1% of $40k when they're 24. It's a function of their spending behaviors when they experience a doubling of income.

@CPAPlanner @CarolynMcC I would posit that when people learn "you should feel good about saving 1%" get a $10k raise, they save $100 of it and feel good. Maybe they even up it to $500 (ooh, now I'm saving 5%!).

When in reality their lifestyle grows faster than savings & they fall BEHIND that way.

@CPAPlanner @CarolynMcC I would seriously challenge you to show that people who save 1% of their income in their 20s have any materially different outcome in their financial trajectory in subsequent decades.

I don't believe that would have any material impact on later savings behaviors. Seriously.
@CPAPlanner @CarolynMcC I'm not framing it in ways that work for me. Bach's "The Latte Factor" sold more than 1M copies with that advice. ;)

@CPAPlanner @CarolynMcC When you convert income growth curves to actual dollar terms, early savings habits like "just try to save 10% - 20%" create unrealistic savings obligations in early years, and actually build BAD savings habits in subsequent higher-earning years.

@CPAPlanner @CarolynMcC Whereas if you tell someone to try to save 10% to 20% of their income (because that's "all they can maybe sorta might be able to do" in their 20s), by their early 40s that's the habit you taught.

So now they're only saving $10k - $20k/year w/ savings habit, instead of $40k.

@CPAPlanner @CarolynMcC If someone's income goes from $40k in their 20s to $100k by their early 40s, and all they do is "just" maintain slight increases in their lifestyle, they could go from "I can't save anything" to "I can save 40% of my income".

@CPAPlanner @CarolynMcC Yes, by 40 the real increases are gone... and your income has DOUBLED by that point. 

Someone's ability to save when their income doubles doesn't go up by a little. It goes up by a LOT. In fact, "save X% of income" causes UNDERSAVING at that point.

@CPAPlanner @CarolynMcC Think about that for a moment.

Person: "I don't make enough money to save!"

Advisor 1: "Well, you should still be saving something! Why are you spending so much on coffee!"

Advisor 2: "Let's figure out how to help you earn more, & then save some of that!"

Which motivates?

@CPAPlanner @CarolynMcC That aside, if you don't earn enough to pay off student debt & afford your rent, and NEVER will get raises, "saving" isn't your biggest problem. Your problem is figuring out how to grow career/earnings to be able to afford to do so. Which still means "savings" is wrong focus.
@CPAPlanner @CarolynMcC A lot of chickens whose hatching is extremely well documented research about how real earnings grow over a person's lifetime? https://t.co/hJanT9O1mF

@CPAPlanner @CarolynMcC "Praise them for doing the habit of saving" = "If you're literally unable to save, you will never be praised". 

So if you can't save RIGHT NOW, you're not praise-worthy? How does that feed into someone's self-worth & self-confidence through years of student loan debt? Ouch. :/

#FA Success Ep 301: Guiding Clients To Design Their Rich Life With A Focus On Spending Dials Not Goals, With Ramit Sethi https://t.co/gMsmSCGyd5 @ramit #Advicers #PersonalFinance #FinancialPsychology https://t.co/EDz53WYZrH

@CPAPlanner @CarolynMcC Except they can't. They. Literally. Can't. There's. No. Money. Left.

When you do everything you're saying to someone who literally CAN'T save, it can be soul-crushing. It obliterates confidence. It fuels feelings of helplessness.

@ThePooreJoe @CPAPlanner There are some models out there. We've written about them at https://t.co/hJanT9O1mF and https://t.co/8DSu3krLpe amongst others.

Problem is historically industry was paid to sell investment products. Save later = broker doesn't get paid. So industry pushed "SAVE NOW!" :/

@CPAPlanner Young people in their 20s are increasingly buried in student loan debt & daunted by ever being able to afford a house & the industry guilts them for not ALSO saving on TOP of the debt & burdensome rent? That doesn't build habits, it can destroy habit-building confidence forever.

@CPAPlanner When it's not an economically feasible habit to build in the first place, pushing that doesn't build the habit, it decimates self-confidence and REDUCES the likelihood the habit will EVER be built.

@CPAPlanner @CarolynMcC Because we told them "you're bad at saving [because you couldn't save much in your 20s]" which cements a self-image of "I'm not a good saver" which almost inevitably becomes a self-fulfiling prophecy. 

Thus why we wrote https://t.co/hJanT9O1mF and also https://t.co/8DSu3krLpe

@CPAPlanner @CarolynMcC But again, model we have right now is that what people DO is closer to the lifecycle model, what we TELL them is "you should feel guilty/awful b/c you're not saving a lot in your 20s" & by the time they get raises they say "screw it, I'm already behind, just gonna spend it now"

@CPAPlanner @CarolynMcC Irony is that while lifecycle finance is an Econ model of saving, from the psychology perspective, it's also arguably a *MUCH* better model to teach people a behaviorally-constructive path to saving than telling them to save when they're unable to do so & guilting them over it.

@CPAPlanner @CarolynMcC Lifecycle model acknowledges inability to save in early career years is a NORMAL result of BEING early-career and not having yet built your income. It normalizes "you can't save early, get ready to save when your income goes up" instead of "you must save! <can't> <gives up>"

@CPAPlanner @CarolynMcC Exactly the point. We tell young people to save when they actually can't, so they give up on industry advice and don't try to start saving when they really can. It's learned helplessness. That's what happens when 'bad' advice is given; literally worse than no advice.

@CPAPlanner The more impactful part, though, is that shellacking young people for NOT saving when they CAN'T save can make them give up on ever saving and then they don't even TRY when they actually CAN.

Psych research knows this as "learned helplessness".

@CPAPlanner The point of the model is not "young people shouldn't plan to save". The point of the model is "it's a normal expected thing that young people won't be ABLE to save" in their early years. Haven't built their careers yet, biggest raises tend to come IN your 20s & early 30s.

@CPAPlanner Given so many young people aren't saving now because they literally can't afford to, I'd argue reality is that this is what's ALREADY happening - people 'dis-save' when they're young, start saving later when they can, slow savings when kids arrive, & catch up during empty nest.
@MegBartelt @DavidPOLeary @MarkMcGrathCFP Did I hear you say "plan to write up a blog about why..."? üëÄ ü§£

@ADHDMoneyTalk @TKopelman Overstating the case a little - when one client is unhappy, it's on them. When 10 clients are unhappy, it's on you.

Make sure you don't have 10-at-a-time problems, because we can't really solve the one-at-a-time problems that aren't actually our problem being expressed. :)

@ADHDMoneyTalk @TKopelman We have a similar challenge within our team. It's natural that the complaints rattle us, and one complaint 'hurts' more than 10 compliments.

Philosophy I've always had is "data over anecdotes". Look to retention rates (people vote w/ their feet) not one-off client unhappiness.

@ADHDMoneyTalk @TKopelman But if clients achieved what they wanted to achieve and they're 'graduating' out, that doesn't mean you let them down, it literally means you helped them accomplish EVERYTHING they wanted to accomplish for the fee they were paying, such that they feel 'done"?

@babs_73 @MegBartelt @BillWinterberg But the key to relieving the tension to me was "the more you narrow the scope (specialize), the easier it is to get to a comfortable place". More limited scope really is more finite and knowable.

@babs_73 @MegBartelt @BillWinterberg I still enjoy learning so the specializations evolve every ~3 years as well. First it was annuities, then AMT, then retirement withdrawals, then retirement tax, etc., over the span of about 10-12 years.

@babs_73 @MegBartelt @BillWinterberg The "Freedom" for me came when I finally picked something to specialize in. Then I didn't have to keep going forever. A specialization has a limited domain of knowledge before you really do know pretty much everything to know in that domain. Deeper was easier than broader.

@babs_73 @MegBartelt @BillWinterberg For me that was the drive for the alphabet soup of degrees and designations. It was a roughly 7 year journey from 2000 - 2007 for me of being continuously enrolled for more programs. The more I learned the more I learned what I still didn't know.

@babs_73 @MegBartelt @BillWinterberg I had a similar feeling. First you don't even know what you don't know. Then as you start learning... And realize how much more you still don't know. Learning models call this transition from unconscious incompetence to conscious incompetence. It feels worse. ü§£

@peter_worn So the opportunity is to say "It's not a 'Good Advice' standard, because they're not advisors, they're salespeople. Let them have a 'Good Sales' standard. Fine. But then they're NOT allowed to call themselves 'advisors' b/c they're not operating in advice capacity."

@peter_worn The big challenge here (and in other countries) is that the product manufacturers and distributors want to USE the advisor title (because it gets product sold) but don't want to adhere to the advisor STANDARD that goes with it. That's what creates consumer confusion.

@peter_worn There is a long-standing similar duty here in the US. The movement we've been pushing here is to get clear on the differences between an ADVISOR and a SALESPERSON. Consumers can (and should!) have access to both, but salespeople are NOT advisors.

@scott_r_frank @DonovanBrooks_ @RightCapitalHQ @AssetMapLLC @Get_Elements Financial Monitoring opportunity isn't just about RightCapital vs Elements.

Our data suggests a sizable portion of eMoney's user base is primarily buying eMoney for its portal, too, as a financial monitoring tool (and then take the planning software along with it).

@DonovanBrooks_ @scott_r_frank @RightCapitalHQ @AssetMapLLC So end result is stagnant/declining market share for most incumbents. While RightCapital, which as a newer player didn't have those B/D enterprises to distract them, launched with planning-centric RIAs, & so that's who they're listening to. Results speak for themselves.

@DonovanBrooks_ @scott_r_frank @RightCapitalHQ @AssetMapLLC So most FP software companies went "downmarket" with simpler software for sales-oriented reps who still don't care & won't use it. In the meantime, increasingly sophisticated planners mostly reject the simpler tools & don't use them either.

@DonovanBrooks_ @scott_r_frank @RightCapitalHQ @AssetMapLLC Problem is for reps who built careers selling products w/o planning, ANY planning is "unnecessary" & wastes time. Planning tools that take 3 seconds would still be 3 too many, & makes clients ask FP questions they don't WANT to answer (takes time, & were getting the sale anyway).

@DonovanBrooks_ @scott_r_frank @RightCapitalHQ @AssetMapLLC The feedback from broker-dealers for years has been "our reps don't want to use your financial planning software, they say it takes too long". So most of the FP software providers tried to make simpler less comprehensive (i.e., "faster") tools, listening to their enterprises.

@noblehillplan Though in the coming years, I think the biggest challenge for margins will simply be the overall shortage of real advisor talent, which is going to drive up base salaries for advisors & make it harder for firms that try hire under 'eat-what-you-kill' models.

@noblehillplan I do think there will be continued margin compression for those who can't scale up to be huge, and don't choose to niche to gain the efficiencies of specialization. I call this the "dangerous middle" https://t.co/ucFC4LgG6p

@noblehillplan Large firms are finding ways to do this at scale (so they can deliver the added services without squeezing margins), and smaller firms are niching and specializing so they can differentiate & win business without needing to do more-more-more.
@noblehillplan In practice, there was some evidence of margin compression from 2015-2020 (where margins were steady or declining despite the strong bull market). Though they seem to have stabilized.

@noblehillplan I don't consider margin compression to be the same as fee compression. It's an alternative to. This is actually how we've expected the 'robo-advisor' phase to play out all along. See https://t.co/bZJe9pgkAQ

@Rick_Ferri @TomMahoneyUBS @dollarsanddata @WadePfau Indeed. They may have a relatively volatile standard of living - most people are not accustomed to adjusting spending by the volatility of income/market returns - but you can't "run out" if you only spend the income.

@dollarsanddata (At least for those with primarily-portfolio-based retirements. The dynamics are a bit different for those who mostly or fully rely on Social Security and especially w/ non-inflation-adjusting other fixed income streams for retirement. But there the 'Puzzle' should be BIGGER!)

@dollarsanddata If you look at the retirement income sustainability research (or even just the math of amortizing retirement assets), the retirees are actually doing it more 'correctly' to spend their assets in retirement than the researchers publishing on the "Puzzle" that actually isn't.

@dollarsanddata They literally aren't doing even just the simple math of how to amortize a base of assets over a long time period with rising expenses over time. If you "spend all the income" now, it doesn't sustain as inflation compounds. And that's before also considering sequence risk.

@dollarsanddata Most of the research on the "Retirement Savings Puzzle" has a fundamental misunderstanding of how spend-downs work in even a modest inflation environment. DELIBERATE spend-down to $0 in 30 years would still spend LESS than income for 15+ years. See https://t.co/Ou9ZeDT2yK

Client Cash Management: Why It's Important, And The Next Generation Of Technology To Make It Better - https://t.co/NwpnGSH2R6 @bhenrymoreland #Advicers #CashManagement #InterestRates https://t.co/sdKEQXZmb9

@Laneylawyer @FinAdvisorCheck Especially since the whole point of that question is to evaluate them relative ot a benchmark. If the markets had a great bull market and the advisor had "great returns", that wasn't the advisor, that was the market. Evaluating manager value-add is about incremental performance.

@Laneylawyer @FinAdvisorCheck But yes, I do think it's reasonable to ask - who wouldn't want to understand a manager's track record for performance. With the caveat that when advisors make (truly) customized portfolios for each client, there isn't really anything clear & consistent TO report on.

@Laneylawyer @FinAdvisorCheck And obviously that presumes the advisor is being hired primarily (or at least materially) FOR their portfolio management services, which isn't always the case. Some are planning-only or advice-only.

@Laneylawyer If the advisor's investment approach is more model-based (which in point of fact is increasingly common), then the gold standard here is to ask for their GIPS track record (as @FinAdvisorCheck & others have pointed out). GIPS has reqs to standardized reporting to minimize gaming.

@Laneylawyer It's fair to ask, but the huge asterisk-caveat to it is that the more customized portfolios are for each client, the less there is any meaningful way to report on a consolidated track record for the advisor's performance.

@JacobHoltgrieve I'd envision a world where prospective advisors are hired onto teams, to serve existing clients (zero prospecting), delivering services under established advisors (strong mentoring framework) while training & learning. Think "residency" models. https://t.co/ttKvo4YZ2A

@JacobHoltgrieve Thus far, the profession has been weak on building such career paths, b/c the model was predicated on product sales (which means new advisors were simply hired to find new clients to sell). But that's changing as the advice models change.

@TiggXXX Cynicism is part of identity for us Gen-Xers! :)

@TiggXXX Though I do agree with you that "modern fiduciary" could be better enforced as well. The SEC in practice has a pretty permissive fiduciary standard (at least compared to ERISA), and allows more conflicts than others. But again it's still a far cry above suitability and Reg BI.

@TiggXXX Not that I don't have concerns about some opaque structured products as well. But the scale of what's permitted in non-fiduciary is truly astounding. In my B/D days I saw 20% commission annuities being sold and it was entirely permissible under non-fiduciary FINRA suitability.

@TiggXXX Brokerage realm and insurance agents can still sell annuities with 10%+ upfront commissions.

Even "expensive" structured notes less problematic than what's already sold in the non-fiduciary environment. In other words, fiduciary already screening more than you may realize?

@CLewandowskiCFP That is why fiduciary accountability matters. It's not about the aspirational code of conduct for good advisors (good character does it anyway). It's for the salespeople who really are just trying to enrich themselves and legally CAN under a non-fiduciary sales standard. :(

@CLewandowskiCFP Per separate tweet...  if my sole goal is to enrich myself by taking 10% of every prospect's wealth  after a 1hr meeting, I can't do that under fiduciary standard. But I can as a rep/agent if the customer signs the app for that 10% commission product and it was "not unsuitable".

@CLewandowskiCFP And fully agree that an advisors character is not defined by a regulator. That's not the purpose of a fiduciary standard.

The purpose is to have consequences for those of "bad character" so consumers have recourse if they're harmed.

@CLewandowskiCFP Well notably, even the SEC in Reg BI bars brokers from calling themselves advisors because it's deemed to be an inaccurate disclosure of their capacity.

Advisor title is only permitted for B/D reps in the first place if they're dually registered so they can give advice as RIAs.

@TiggXXX That's why fiduciary matters. It's not about the aspirational code of conduct for good advisors (who as you note, do it anyway). It's for the salespeople who really are just trying to enrich themselves and legally CAN under a non-fiduciary sales standard. :(

@TiggXXX If my sole goal is to enrich myself by taking 10% of the wealth of every prospect I meet after a 1 hour meeting, I cannot do that under a fiduciary standard. But I can as a rep/agent if the customer signs the app for that 10% commission product and it was "not unsuitable".

@TiggXXX Yes fully true that good advisors adhere to what a fiduciary standard would require. However, there's a difference between doing it by choice and being legally accountable to it even if I don't want to adhere to it.

@fundhunter_co I wish it was your version - asking about reasonable return expectations relative to their goals, as in practice that certain IS a question we have with (new) clients. But alas, that wasn't the context here. This was an advisor-shopping question. :(
@dvjamieson First two are huge and very underappreciated. :(

@PhilBillingham Low capacity doesn't mean the downside is worse than the upside. It just means they will have challenges if the downside happens.

When A Roth IRA May Actually Be A Terrible Asset To Inherit - https://t.co/y9qvuPP1h7 https://t.co/byBmKEuzsw

@PhilBillingham Granted, I think those are super-problematic sitations as advisors, because it puts us in an awful position if they take risks they can't afford and then it goes poorly for them. But their choices are their choices. Though often they'll pursue such courses of action w/o us.

@PhilBillingham People who have a strong willingness DO take risks with weak capacity. Not something I'm a fan of seeing, but it's reality. From investors who swing for the fences, to entrepreneurs who start a business w/ little savings. People w/ high willingness to take risks, do.

Notably, there *ARE* good advisors who don't fit this criteria (not RIAs, don't charge fees, not CFPs, etc.). But VERY hard for consumers to tell, which leads to bad vetting Qs. Thus my 'Advice to Mom' approach: narrow the search to those w/ higher standards to begin with. (/end)

That's why incentives, accountability, & education/expertise matter so much. THOSE you can vet. And if you're well-aligned on THOSE, you should be able to sleep well at night that the "Advicer" is really looking out for you and your interests. https://t.co/jOXjGbqF3i (24/?)

Obviously there are lots of other nuances w/ particular services & pricing (fit there obviously matters too), but ultimately the whole point of hiring an expert is that you can't fully vet their expertise, so you have to vet what you can. (23/?)

In practice, the first 3 categories alone eliminate most 'financial advisors'. The Venn diagram of incentives (fees), accountability (fiduciary), and education (CFP+), is already quite small. Refine further from there seeking expertise & communication fit. (22/?)

Seek out an advisor that feels comfortable to talk to and communicate with, and trust your gut that if it doesn‚Äôt feel right in the first meeting, it‚Äôs not going to be a good fit in the long run either. Always vet w/ a final 1-hour conversation to make sure you get along. (21/?)

5) Communication matters. In the end, open conversation about your money issues w/ your advisor is crucial. Yet money is still one of the most taboo subjects. So even if someone checks the other boxes, if you don't feel the communication click, it's not a good fit. (20/?)
Seek out advisors who have experience with (and ideally, a focus in) working with other clients of a similar income/wealth level and age/circumstances to you. (19/?)

Educated adivsors run projections to see if you can afford to retire; expertise is knowing pre-65 transition creates pre-Medicare health insurance gap, an HDHP w/ HSA can bridge the gap, but claiming SS early triggers Medicare application & invalidates HSA contributions. (18/?)

4) Expertise matters. Education covers the core body of knowledge, while expertise is about applied experience gleaned from helping lots of people in situations like yours. And the wisdom that comes from seeing those client challenges & solving them repeatedly. (17/?)
Seek out CFP certificants (which inherently includes several years of experience required to earn the marks), and more years of experience & advanced designations for highly complex needs. (16/?)

If you want good advice, demand more competency. That means CFP certification as a bare minimum, and ideally a graduate degree in finanical planning or another relevant field or other advanced designations (esp. if your situation is more complex). (15/?)

3) Education matters. The bar to put "financial advisor" on your business card & advise on someone's entire life savings is ludicrously low - it's a high school diploma & a 3-hour regulatory exam you can study for in a week or two (& the diploma is actually optional). (14/?)

Fiduciary is the advice standard, w/ real legal consequences for those giving bad advice & don't follow a good process. Seek out an RIA who operates as a fiduciary at all times. (And look them up on BrokerCheck to verify no disciplinary history.) https://t.co/1rDTkeMI7a (13/?)

2) Accountability matters. Salespeople have different (lower) standards of care than advisors - in our industry, broker-dealer reps & insurance agents (salespeople) have lower standards than RIAs (advice-givers). You want an advisor who has consequences for bad advice. (12/?)

1) Incentives matter. Most 'financial advisors' are legally salespeople, not advisors, paid for products they sell (commissions) rather than the advice they give (fees). And when you're paid to sell hammers, every problem looks like a nail. Seek out a "fee-only" advisor. (11/?)
So what SHOULD consumers ask when they're vetting a financial advisor? Here's the "What I'd tell my mother if she had to find a financial advisor alone after I'm gone" advice I give... (10/?)

Key point is that, especially in low-return environments, asking advisors what returns they can get pulls you away from 'good' advisors w/ realistic advice about low returns, & skews towards those who overpromise & then dial up risk trying to make good. Which is NOT good. (9/?)

Because the return environment was what it was. We were all invested in the same opportunities. But b/c the prospect evaluated advisors by their promised returns, he picked the one w/ the highest %-return promises that really just gave the riskiest portfolio.üò™ (8/?)

And so barely 4 years later, along comes the financial crisis. ~30% of his portfolio was in Lehman preferred. He got the promised 8% yields for 4 years... until nearly 1/3rd of his portfolio lost 99% in a few weeks when Lehman went under. (7/?)

Meanwhile, second advisor was telling the prospect he'd get 8% returns. So the prospect picked them. 8% beats 6%. Except it really was a low-return environment (10-yr returns ended up ~6%), so 8% was only achievable w/ concentration in high-dividend #FinServ preferred. (6/?)

But here's why it matters. Back in 2004 we had a prospective client ask this year - when real estate was booming but rates were really low and valuations were already getting high. As memory serves, we told the client 6% - 7% was all we could expect over 10 years. (5/?)

At best, some market fundamentals can give guidance over the next 5-10+ years that returns will be better (above-average) or worse (below-average), but even brilliant managers fail to beat the market routinely in any particular year (b/c no one knows year to year). (4/?)

In other words, advisor might get 6% where the market delivered 5%, or 16% when the market was 15%, or -19% when the market was -20%. All beat by 1%. But whether the market returns 5% or 15% or -20%, the truth is no one knows for any particular year. (3/?)

First & foremost, the reality is that returns are determined by the market, not the advisor. At best, an advisor may say they can beat the market BY a certain amount (1% or whatever?), but that's still relative to whatever the market turns out to deliver. (2/?)

Just got the infamous (for advisors) question that prospects often ask: "what % return should I expect to get if I hire your firm?"

Feeling compelled to take a few minutes & explain why this is NOT what any consumer should ever ask when trying to vet a financial advisor... (1/?)

@Zack_Hubbard1 @R_Alan_Moore @XYPlanning @fpassociation Ha. I don't think @fpassociation sucks, though. Yes, I've been critical of their strategy & execution at times, but I'm a dues-paying member, and speak out BECAUSE I think what the FPA does actually matters so much.

@Zack_Hubbard1 @R_Alan_Moore @XYPlanning @fpassociation But again, I don't think FPA wants to "control the title" to the exclusion of others. It's profession-focused. But rejecting the Coalition, & not supporting SEC petition on Title Protection, to go its own "mystery" path it won't share, definitely has many scratching their heads.

@Zack_Hubbard1 @R_Alan_Moore @XYPlanning @fpassociation Doesn't have to be the outcome - obviously we hope for better! - but it's the big concern if FPA pursues state regs. Even more so if it doesn't form a Coalition to support it. Which is hard as FPA rejects CFP Board's Federal approach & XYPN's Title Protection petition w/ the SEC.

@Zack_Hubbard1 @R_Alan_Moore @XYPlanning @fpassociation And at that point, we'll have actually enshrined an even LOWER, NON-FIDUCIARY standard for the "Financial Planner" title, that's now enshrined in law across 50 states at that lower level, and the @FPAssociation will have put us into a worse place that we are already today.

@Zack_Hubbard1 @R_Alan_Moore @XYPlanning @fpassociation So the end-game risk is that FPA convinces state regulators to regulate the "Financial Planner" title, and then broker-dealer lobbysts from SIFMA & FSI, who have VASTLY more lobbying resources, hit all 50 statehouses to get the Series 6 as minimum baseline for "Financial Planner"

@Zack_Hubbard1 @R_Alan_Moore @XYPlanning @fpassociation For which FPA has no Coalition. And may open this Pandora's box in 50 states at once. While being grossly out-resourced by the product industry...

@Zack_Hubbard1 @R_Alan_Moore @XYPlanning @fpassociation And at best, it takes a strong coalition of stakeholders to push regulators to only include "their" standards and not water down across other stakeholders as well...

@Zack_Hubbard1 @R_Alan_Moore @XYPlanning @fpassociation ...Because if FPA pushes for regulation on titles, regulators will look to get input from ALL stakeholders. Which means there's a real risk that the title gets watered down to the lowest common denominator of stakeholders who give input...

@Zack_Hubbard1 @R_Alan_Moore @XYPlanning @fpassociation In the end, I don't think @fpassociation wants to "control the title for themselvs". That's not really how regulation ends out working. My concern is actually the opposite...

@Zack_Hubbard1 @R_Alan_Moore @XYPlanning @fpassociation So real questions at this point: 1) What exactly is FPA planning to advocate for at the state level?; 2) What resources can it really commit to do it?; 3) Can FPA do it when they have disengaged on prior SEC petitions for title reform & / states like CO on FP regulation?

@Zack_Hubbard1 @R_Alan_Moore @XYPlanning @fpassociation Which raises the real concern about FPA pursuing state-level regulation for title protection - does @fpassociation even have the resources to fight this fight, across 50 states, when it couldn't even marshall resources for a comment letter in one state (Colorado) on one FP issue?

@Zack_Hubbard1 @R_Alan_Moore @XYPlanning @fpassociation Though bizarrely, even as @fpassociation is talking about state-level advocacy on financial planning, it has been silent on Colorado's very-problematic state rules. Instead, XYPN had to file Comment alone, again.

#FA Success Ep 294: Developing COI Referrals With Attorneys From An Attorney-Turned-Advisor, With Neel Shah https://t.co/4wdZQRefEG @ShahPlan #Advicers #COIs #Referrals #Attorneys https://t.co/aWlDoAQfzC

@Zack_Hubbard1 @R_Alan_Moore @XYPlanning @fpassociation The rapid growth of non-AUM financial planning models at the state level - driven in large part by rapid growth of XYPN - is why we're seeing state regulators now trying to react. Thus the 'Guidance' that came out recently from Colorado, for example.

@Zack_Hubbard1 @R_Alan_Moore @XYPlanning @fpassociation Though at the same time, the regulatory battle on financial planning IS increasingly becoming state-centric. Because "pure" financial planning doesn't entail much or any AUM, which means financial planners will increasingly be state-registered, not SEC.

@Zack_Hubbard1 @R_Alan_Moore @XYPlanning @fpassociation From the XYPN perspective, we somewhat agree - we filed our SEC Petitions to pursue title reform w/ the SEC specifically because it would be Federal, and would leverage existing laws so there's no new layers of regulation that could/would emerge if done at the state level.

@Zack_Hubbard1 @R_Alan_Moore @XYPlanning @fpassociation Rift between FPA & CFP Board in Coalition isn't surprising, though, in that FPA has signaled that it is likely to pursue a state path to title reform, while CFP Board has been public in saying they want to focus on (nationally-uniform) Federal regulation. https://t.co/POwkCXJ2ZN

@Zack_Hubbard1 @R_Alan_Moore @XYPlanning Was definitely frustrating that @fpassociation didn't show any support for XYPN Title Reform efforts. Especially given that it was the FPA's lawsuit that vacated in 2007 the "Financial Planner" title protection the SEC had already granted! Which XYPN asked the SEC to reinstate.

@Zack_Hubbard1 @R_Alan_Moore @XYPlanning Well when it comes to title protection, we support the direction at @XYPlanning, as this was literally the central issue of the first of two Petitions that we submitted to the SEC last year. See https://t.co/dR8Aw1IklP and https://t.co/k8GOMdRNha

@RFrailich @Steph_Bogan Very much appreciate the conversation and your willingness to say something here, Ryan.

@RFrailich @Steph_Bogan Not that you 'have to' charge that high or more, or even 'should'. But also you shouldn't feel bad/guilty if you do choose to serve clients who want to pay at that level for services they value at that level. 

(Sadly, we have high-fee shaming AND low-fee shaming in our world.)

@RFrailich @Steph_Bogan Though I do also concur w/ what at least I see as Steph's underlying point, which is that a lot of advisors make implied judgments (on others or even themselves) about what is "too high" of a fee to be fair/appropriate, and Steph is trying to re-anchor us to much-higher numbers.

@RFrailich @Steph_Bogan In other words, when it's one consumer's expectation of what it may cost to get their desired "level of awesome", I think "cool, you do you" and connect w/ Steph.

If it's an implication of what all advisors 'should' be doing, it gets challenging and I'm in Ryan's camp. ;)

@RFrailich @Steph_Bogan I think there's a key distinction here that Steph framed this as "the level of awesome *I'm* expecting" which can be very specific to her goals and expectations from an advisor.

Though I see how Ryan (& many others) would view it as a general statement of 'all advisors'?

@RetirementRisks @jasonpereira @thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @TKopelman @behaviorgap @XYPlanning @AbundoW But debates about "what is the 'best' fee model" are actually fundamentally different than the debate about "compensation [fees vs commissions]". The latter was about distinguishing advice from sales. The former is about differentiating amongst advice-givers for advice clients.

@RetirementRisks @jasonpereira @thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @TKopelman @behaviorgap @XYPlanning @AbundoW Obviously there's also a huge range of differentiation challenges and opportunities WITHIN advice-givers as well - and it's becoming more 'problematic' as more people become advice-givers, which is why you now see growing battles within the fee-charging community about models.

@RetirementRisks @jasonpereira @thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @TKopelman @behaviorgap @XYPlanning @AbundoW But again, it was never actually literally about compensation or fiduciary. It was about the difference between advice and product sales. However, because of poor regulation of titles, advice-givers only COULD distinguish themselves by compensation & standards.

@RetirementRisks @jasonpereira @thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @TKopelman @behaviorgap @XYPlanning @AbundoW Fiduciary similarly gained traction - despite poor consumer understanding of the legal jargon - because it was an actual differentiator between advice & sales, that only applied to the advice-givers and not the salespeople.

@RetirementRisks @jasonpereira @thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @TKopelman @behaviorgap @XYPlanning @AbundoW And fee-only vs commissions gained traction in part because it actually was a decent differentiator. There are concrete differences in licensing and regulation between the two (b/c there actually is a difference between advice vs sales that regulators have long recognized).

@RetirementRisks @jasonpereira @thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @TKopelman @behaviorgap @XYPlanning @AbundoW Except you couldn't say "I give advice and the other person doesn't" becuase the other person had "financial advisor" on their business card as well.

So the industry shifted to talking about fees vs commissions, b/c that still distinguished advice from sales.

@RetirementRisks @jasonpereira @thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @TKopelman @behaviorgap @XYPlanning @AbundoW Yes, but it's that way in law in part b/c the whole minimum standard - for both competency and conduct - is higher in the first place.

Point of fee-only was never really "fees are best", per se. It was "I'm not a salesperson paid on commission". Distinguishing advice vs sales.

@MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @FranklyFinances @jasonfrieds @Zack_Hubbard1 @TKopelman @behaviorgap @thehannahjmoore But whether consumers value the ice cream or the cherry won't be determined by the $10 bill, it'll be determined by how generously the restaurant lays on the ice cream.

@MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @FranklyFinances @jasonfrieds @Zack_Hubbard1 @TKopelman @behaviorgap @thehannahjmoore Not to fully defend 'bundling' over not in all cases. Clearly a wide range of scenarios where we want/prefer to consume services a la carte and unbundled.

Point is just that we're not always happier unbundled, & value of the bundle is based on where businesses PUT the value.

@MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @FranklyFinances @jasonfrieds @Zack_Hubbard1 @TKopelman @behaviorgap @thehannahjmoore Fully unbundled airline pricing would have every passenger step on a scale before thety get onto the airplane, and adjust the airline ticket mid-flight if the plane has to take an alternative route.

I don't anticipate consumers would be happier with the outcome. ;)

@MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @FranklyFinances @jasonfrieds @Zack_Hubbard1 @TKopelman @behaviorgap @thehannahjmoore Airlines are an interesting example. Their actual business model is to transport weight over distance. In fact, it costs more to fly a heavy person than a light one, and men vs women (on average).

But airlines don't sell "transport weight over distance". They sell destinations.

Though there's absolutely still some opportunity in both. :)

@MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @FranklyFinances @jasonfrieds @Zack_Hubbard1 @TKopelman @behaviorgap @thehannahjmoore Granted, bundling isn't always more cost efficient, and sometimes allows more costly offerings to be opaquely hidden within the bundle (though robust competition usually helps weed that out).

But there's a reason why so many businessses bundle, & why many buy bundled services.

@jasonfrieds @MeasureTwiceMNY @Zack_Hubbard1 @TKopelman @behaviorgap @jbrendanfrazier @thehannahjmoore Meta Q is which models have  largest pool of demand and whether the dominant model will shift. That remains to be seen. AUM almost by definition is niche relative to the overall public (most don't have significant investable assets) but it's HUGE b/c literally LOTS of $$$ there.

@jasonfrieds @MeasureTwiceMNY @Zack_Hubbard1 @TKopelman @behaviorgap @jbrendanfrazier @thehannahjmoore But the key here is that competition of new models isn't carving up some fixed pie of limited clients (at least not much from what we can see). It's expanding the whole size of the pie, by expanding reach to new segments of consumers. It's an And, not an Or.

@jasonfrieds @MeasureTwiceMNY @Zack_Hubbard1 @TKopelman @behaviorgap @jbrendanfrazier @thehannahjmoore Consumers are so undeserved by advisors in the aggregate because of the limitations of our business models (of many various types) that almost every new model has opportunity for fast growth with early adopters that move into new undeserved segments. Cody's growth good example.

@jasonfrieds @MeasureTwiceMNY @Zack_Hubbard1 @TKopelman @behaviorgap @jbrendanfrazier @thehannahjmoore Our (admittedly limited but some) Kitces Research data on subscription models in general shows they're not growing at the expense of AUM but with a different demographic of Non-AUM clients.

Would expect similar with Advice-Only but to an even greater extent. Less overlap.

@jasonfrieds @MeasureTwiceMNY @Zack_Hubbard1 @TKopelman @behaviorgap @jbrendanfrazier @thehannahjmoore Advice-Only is new enough as a framework for communicating with consumers that I don't know if we have much data or knowledge to clarify demand.

Broader point to me is simply by definition Advice-Only engagements don't involve delegation. Which means a different psychographic.

@thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @TKopelman @behaviorgap @XYPlanning @AbundoW Firms like Commonwealth and LPL are increasingly describing themselves as RIA platforms with broker-dealer affiliates that may someday spin off and go away. Even more and more of the brokerage industry itself sees fees and advice as the future.

@thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @TKopelman @behaviorgap @XYPlanning @AbundoW If you look industry-wide, the top-50 independent broker-dealers - whose literal regulatory purpose is to serve as an intermediary for commission-based product sales - generate the majority of their revenue from fees, not products. Has been that way for almost 5 years.

@thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @TKopelman @behaviorgap @XYPlanning @AbundoW However, that doesn't change the reality that the future of building a profession is likely going to follow the path that every other profession follows, which is the ongoing separation of product distribution from advice delivery. So we try to show/illustrate those paths.

@thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @TKopelman @behaviorgap @XYPlanning @AbundoW We built the Advicer framework recognizing that a lot of advisors are currently in product-based environment but have a genuinely advice-centric offering and value proposition. They're welcomed on Kitces.

@thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @TKopelman @behaviorgap @XYPlanning @AbundoW Though strictly speaking, that's why our "Advicer" standards at https://t.co/jOXjGbqF3i are intentionally written based on "advice" as a value prop, and NOT written based on compensation model. (Though they do require fiduciary accountability which is fee-centric in practice.)

@thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @TKopelman @behaviorgap @XYPlanning @AbundoW The question to me is: what does it take to help those advisors adapt and evolve to where the professional standards are going? 

If there are pathways to get there, those who don't follow the path are making their own choice at that point?

@thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @TKopelman @behaviorgap @XYPlanning @AbundoW It's not meant to be exclusionary, per se, but every recognized professional creates lines that divide the recognized professionals from others who may have similar personal skillsets but aren't operating by those professional standards.

@thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @TKopelman @behaviorgap @XYPlanning @AbundoW In point of fact, that's why you don't see legal advice within advisory firms. Legal ethics determined that long ago that law firms have to be owned BY lawyers, to force separation of legal advice from products that might be sold/implemented pursuant to that advice.

@thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @TKopelman @behaviorgap @XYPlanning @AbundoW The roadmap to being a profession isn't being pulled out of thin air. Medicine, law, and accounting, have all been down this path, and ultimately recognized the need to separate products from advice. Both matter, but the advice-providers aren't employed by product manufacturers.

@thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @TKopelman @behaviorgap @XYPlanning @AbundoW And while yes, I'm sure there are models of bringing medical services to underserved communities by just having the doctors get paid by the drug companies to prescribe more drugs into those communities, that's long since been rejected as a sound model for medical advice.

@thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @TKopelman @behaviorgap @XYPlanning @AbundoW In the medical context, we absolutely NEED drug companies to manufacture and distribute, and pharmacists to fill those prescriptions, and doctors to write those prescriptions.

But the doctors aren't giving medical advice while employed by drug companies to sell their drugs.

@thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @jbrendanfrazier @TKopelman @behaviorgap @XYPlanning @AbundoW The point isn't to define financial planning by a fee model. It's to define financial planning by a service.

Advice is a fundamentally different service than product sales/distribution. Different economics, different metrics, different regulations & standards, different outcomes

@thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @TKopelman @behaviorgap @jbrendanfrazier @XYPlanning Most @XYPlanning advisors we see start very mid-market, but move further upmarket within just a few years b/c of the demand of clients willing to pay a lot more to get access to an advisor when capacity is so limited.

@thehannahjmoore @MeasureTwiceMNY @TKopelman @behaviorgap @jbrendanfrazier @XYPlanning There are 90,000 CFPs in total, and most advisors top out at <100 clients. So there's only enough of us to serve ~9M households. There are 130M in the US.

All models tend to skew 'upmarket' right now b/c advisor shortage causes high end clients to bid up advisors upmarket.

@MeasureTwiceMNY @thehannahjmoore @TKopelman @behaviorgap @jbrendanfrazier @XYPlanning And the growth of that model is now driving the development of 'fee-based' products that non-salespeople can prescribe to clients (that don't have the commissions that non-salespeople can't accept anyway). As P. Kemp Fain famously uttered long ago - One Profession, One Designation. Which was all about unifying under a single standard to be recognized as a professional. Title Protection is a foundational element.

Good to see @fpassociation get back into the fray on this!

Real work comes next for FPA, deciding how to operationalize this advocacy goal into real tactics - state or Federal, CFP marks or broader, etc.

But applaud FPA for taking up the issue. It's been a lonely fight, & financial planners all have to align to make it happen!

At its core, though, Title Protection has simple roots - to call yourself a "Financial Planner", you should have to BE one. And research shows titles DO matter: https://t.co/xYiBYfz7yO

Truth-in-advertising is actually a light-touch approach to advisor regulation in this regard.

Ultimately, Title Protection will be divisive, if only b/c "Financial Planner" has been increasingly used by the product industry, that isn't going to want to let it go now. But Title Protection is hugely popular amongst FPA membership (& I think financial planners more broadly).

In fact, the FPA's press release was notably silent on making the CFP marks the benchmark for "financial planner" competency, even as they're the membership association for CFP professionals. Is FPA really considering some other/additional designation to rally around?

That's why the @XYPlanning approach has been to build around the RIA fiduciary framework in the Investment Advisers Act of 1940, and the @CFPBoard's CFP marks. 

Are they perfect? Nope, neither are. But the alternative would just be MORE layers of regulation on TOP of those!

However, in the end "title protection" almost inevitably requires some regulator to license the term (so those not eligible are restricted from using it), and some regulator to enforce it (so standards & their regulatory burden are inevitable). Some regulation is 'inevitable'?

Notably, FPA isn't staking ground to pursue w/ the SEC... at least, not yet(?). 

Instead, "Title Protection" will simply top their advocacy agenda, & begin exploring viable state or Federal paths, w/ goal of 'not creating unnnecessary regulatory burden'. https://t.co/F2amDYsBcm

Big @FPAssociation news today - they'll be pursuing formal protectiong of "Financial Planner" as a title that can't be used w/o meeting competency & ethics standards.

Couldn't agree more. Same thing we argued in our @XYPlanning Petition to SEC last year. https://t.co/dR8Aw1HMwh

@HigherEdCraig @DanielYerger3 @CFPBoard Interesting hot take! Any P&C companies in that space you think are particularly notable and worth watching?
@DanielYerger3 Not trying to attribute to malice. I did use the word "unwittingly" more than once in the article. :)

@DanielYerger3 @CFPBoard Would be great if you'd be willing to leave these comments on the blog post as well, Daniel. Worry that some readers won't see it here on Twitter, and I think it's an important dialogue for the whole CFP community.

@DanielYerger3 Do appreciate constructive criticism you raise about what I wrote. And "demonstrate responsible deployment w/o resources to do said analysis" is a good concern to raise. Just don't think CFP Board's financial wherewithal & prior history support that being a real blocking point.

@DanielYerger3 This is ~$3M/year increase for workforce development, & CFP Board has $30M+ reserves. To suggest "hire an academic to run a study first to prove out the efficacy" is not unreasonable, and easily fundable from existing CFP Board resources or prior/current CfFP contributed income.
@DanielYerger3 Not to mention that to the extent this is now running through the CFP Certification Fee structure and not 'just' the Center, it should bring CFP Board's full resources to bear.

@DanielYerger3 With all due respect, believe this is a very false dichotomy.

Yes, doing a study to analyze the issue isn't 'free'. But CFP Board spent the past 5 years promoting multiple multi-million dollar multi-year corporate sponsors. There's plenty of funding available to research this.

@DanielYerger3 Though per our shared concerns in the CFP Board's Career Guide, I do worry there is at least some 'willful blindness' to not looking at and recognizing the substantial differences in failure rate across entry-level job channels.

@DanielYerger3 I'm not actually assuming the worst of intentions here. I don't believe CFP Board is pushing the program out of malice or to cause churn, but ignorance of not studying the best way to deploy dollars before committing to do it.

@DanielYerger3 To be fair, that probably means Study I suggested in section 3 is too narrow targeting just some larger programs (which I offered only b/c it limits the required resources to be more focused). I'll own the methods faux paus there - at best, should be random sampling of programs!

@DanielYerger3 I hear you on whether 'top-tier' PFP programs tend to send students into sales jobs less. In part it seems that advice-centric firms seem to focus into those programs for their own recruiting, and established programs have more resources to teach students about range of jobs?

@DanielYerger3 @CFPBoard Appreciate your sharing this and the dialogue, Daniel.

@LBridges999 But in context of the original tweet, that was the point - yes, long-term investing can produce some incredible wealth creation. But the nature of compounding means that at 'healthy' growth rates, by definition, the majority of ALL the growth comes in just the last 10 years! /end
@LBridges999 Because again, to have $1M after 40 years means you're not even half way there after 30 years. You're barely 1/5th of the way there ($205k out of $1M) at the half-way (20-year) mark.

@LBridges999 Obviously most of us will never generate Warren's wealth, but the interesting effect from this is that most people drastically underestimate the weatlh accumulation path they're actually on, b/c of how dramatic that compounding effect can be in the final years.

@LBridges999 Similarly, this is why it took Warren Buffet ~35 years (from his early 20s until age 56) to accumulate his first $1B. And in the subsequent 35 years (from then until now) it went from $1B to almost $100B. Compounding.
@LBridges999 Thus why Einstein dubbed compounding "the 8th Wonder of the World". The compounding effects are truly extraordinary!

@LBridges999 At higher growth rates, the compression is even more severe. 

If you're growing at 10%, your pattern is:
Year 10: $80k
Year 20: $286k
Year 30: $822k
Year 40: $2.2M

The final decade nearly 3X's your value. It's even more compressed in the final years.

@LBridges999 So as long as returns average 7%, no matter what wealth is created w/ a long-term investment strategy, by definition more than half of all the growth will come in the final decade. Because the final decade will always end out taking "the balance w/ 10 years to go, and double it".

@LBridges999 Ultimately, it will always play out this way. The simplifying rule for compounding is known as "the rule of 72" - take the growth rate, divide it into 72, and that's how many years it takes for money to double. So at a 7% growth rate, it takes about 72 / 7 = ~10 years.

@LBridges999 So, literally, "the majority' of all the growth comes in the final decade. There's more growth in the last 10 years (from $472k to $1M) than there was in the first 30 years (to get from $0 to $472k).

@LBridges999 But note how that played out at the end:
Year 10: $69k
Year 20: $205k
Year 30: $472k
Year 40: $1M

Even with a 'normal' growth path, you're less than half way there with 'just' 10 years to go!

@LBridges999 And then at 40 years you've reached ~$1M. (With a little rounding. The exact math would be saving $5,009/year if you run it in a spreadsheet or a financial calculator, but close enough for our purposes. ;) )
@LBridges999 By the 30-year mark, the compounding picks up further. You're at $472k, of which $150k were contributions and $322k is growth.

@LBridges999 In the early years, it's really slow. After 10 years, you're only up to $69k (of which $50k is just the $5,000/year savings, and ~$19k is growth).

After 20 years, up to $205k, which at that point is $100k of savings ($5k/year) plus $105k of cumulative growth.
@LBridges999 At a 7% long-term compounding growth rate, it'll take saving about $5,000/year for 40 years for the savings to grow to $1M.
@LBridges999 Let's say you're 25 and have a goal to save $1,000,000 by the time you're age 65. So you have 40 years to save.
@LBridges999 Sure. It's an interesting effect of how compounding plays out... (1/?)

@gspitzner @christine_benz Notably, despite relative breadth of the tech you describe, survey is already showing that 85% of advisors are NOT doing TLH for every client even in 'just' the past 3 months.

2/3rds doing it 'some' or 'selectively'. Very client-specific. (Not so automated?)

@gspitzner @christine_benz Underlying point is TLH is a waste unless, specifically, it generates a positive tax benefit. Which means software has to be "right" 100.0% of the time or the advisor has liability. Which means most firms have a manual review process to verify. So never really 'fully' automated?

@gspitzner @christine_benz Which cuts down the trading frequency to the point that there's not actually much value to looking more intermittently after all. ;) 

Daryanani did a similar study on rebalancing. Built software to do daily rebal, then did a study & found once every 2 weeks was same benefit. :)

@gspitzner @christine_benz Especially since the reality is that if you literally do a fresh TLH harvesting for each miniscule daily decline in the market, even without ticket charges the $0.01 bid/ask spreads may obliterate most or all of the TLH tax deferral benefits.

@gspitzner @christine_benz Continuous daily TLH automation is a fine thing for self-directed consumers to choose to buy, because they're responsible for their own tax situation. 

As an advisor who bears accountability, it's overkill and amplifies risk of tax errors?

@gspitzner @christine_benz Wearing advisor hat, sounds terrifying to me to actually automate on a daily basis without a review system.

Client situations are dynamic, especially for tax purposes. If you accidentally TLH for a client in a low-income year, it DESTROYS wealth. (Step down at 0% rates.)

RIP to the Sit-Up. Long live the Plank! ü§£

@samir_vasavada @AaronKlein @Mark_AFO @RIABiz TAMPs at least stay competitive at 0.25% - 0.35% because advisors charging proverbial 1% AUM fee typically have 35%+ overhead expense in their firms anyway. So the TAMP doesn't stack cost; it competes with existing overhead costs, replacing existing tech + staff expenses.

@samir_vasavada @AaronKlein @Mark_AFO @RIABiz If you're not competitive to Riskalyze and Morningstar and Orion Eclipse then you're an added cost on top of them? That's a tough sale in a world where the driving trend for a decade has been fiduciary advisors stripping out investment product layer costs for clients?

@samir_vasavada @AaronKlein @Mark_AFO @RIABiz Advisors have already been disintermediating mutual fund fees for years. Rebalancing software already facilitates this, leading to advisors running ETF models at lower cost than mutual funds (or Vise). Already underway 5+ years ago. https://t.co/nnAazP3NCg

@samir_vasavada @AaronKlein @Mark_AFO @RIABiz I'm thrilled to see more innovation & more VC dollars driving into our #AdvisorTech world. But our industry is EXTREMELY fragmented, & majority of advisors run their own practices and want tools that match THEIR way of doing business. Which is why best of breed has been dominant.

@samir_vasavada @AaronKlein @Mark_AFO @RIABiz But "you have to replace all your best in breed solutions for an all-in-one tech solution you implement yourself" struggles b/c best in breed already quite solid & switching costs of adopting new systems & retraining staff is very high. And that's before software cost difference.

@samir_vasavada @AaronKlein @Mark_AFO @RIABiz The platforms that manage to actually do this typically end out being TAMPs - because there's a different psychographic of advisor who chooses all-in-one to NOT have to deal with it and outsources it. And the TAMP provider then uses their own full stack to deliver & execute.

@samir_vasavada @AaronKlein @Mark_AFO @RIABiz Others have built similar solutions before. You don't see them in the marketplace b/c they struggled to gain adoption.

Have to beat Riskalyze on Proposals, Morningstar at Analytics/Construction, iRebal on trading, etc., all at the same time. At a higher price point than them?

@wealthtender @jasonfrieds @MeasureTwiceMNY @morganranstrom @AyeshaSelden Depends on your target market. This behavior varies at different wealth levels.

@jasonfrieds @MeasureTwiceMNY @morganranstrom @AyeshaSelden Because in that case, the digital presence didn't source or produce the lead in the first place. It nurtured the lead. That's an important middle-of-funnel function, but that doesn't change the lead source from having been a client referral. :)

@jasonfrieds @MeasureTwiceMNY @morganranstrom @AyeshaSelden That doesn't mean "relying on referrals is dangerous". 

To the contrary, that effectively says "relying on referrals works GREAT, & you can amplify the success of relying on referrals by implementing the supporting parts of a referral marketing funnel, like a digital presence".

@jasonfrieds @MeasureTwiceMNY @morganranstrom @AyeshaSelden I don't disagree that certain aspects of digital presence are an increasingly important factor to support the referral process - even with a referral, prospects often still scope us out online - but that still means it's part of a referral marketing strategy.

@jasonfrieds @MeasureTwiceMNY @morganranstrom @AyeshaSelden If you look at an advisor who has an AWESOME digital presence to support their referrals, such that 100% of their referrals close because of their awesome digital presence, they're still going to say they're growing 100% by client referrals. Which they are. ;)
For advisors with successful consumer-facing podcasts, and opportunity here to nominate yourself and get recognized! https://t.co/30Y87GKAgs
@jasonfrieds @MeasureTwiceMNY @morganranstrom @AyeshaSelden What data are you referring to on this? Source link?

@jasonfrieds @morganranstrom @MeasureTwiceMNY @AyeshaSelden In that context, I'd call referral-based growth strategies "limiting" but not necessarily "dangerous".

Notably, "referral marketing" in this context typically references CLIENT referrals specifically. Other referral sources (COIs, custodians, banks, etc.) are separate.

@jasonfrieds @morganranstrom @MeasureTwiceMNY @AyeshaSelden Granted, I'm VERY upbeat about other non-referral-based marketing strategies as well. Particularly for those who want more scalable growth, or to grow beyond the founder.

But referrals is remarkably effective for slow-and-steady growth, which is where most advisors are anyway.

@jasonfrieds @morganranstrom @MeasureTwiceMNY @AyeshaSelden Except if you're growing w/ referrals, there is by definition a flow of new clients who are replenishing the pool as new untapped sources OF referrals.

That's WHY so many firms have continued to grow & compound successfully with referrals. It at least somewhat self-replenishes.

@MeasureTwiceMNY @morganranstrom @jasonfrieds @AyeshaSelden Well ideally, the results don't just speak for themselves. The satisfied clients speak for themselves... to others. ;) 

But yes. :)

@MeasureTwiceMNY @morganranstrom @jasonfrieds @AyeshaSelden There are many paths to demonstrate the value and benefits of financial planning to the public. You happen to follow a particular approach to it - which is awesome - but it's not the only way.

@MeasureTwiceMNY @morganranstrom @jasonfrieds @AyeshaSelden Or... they're showing the public the value of working with a financial advisor by the brilliant success stories OF their clients, who share that message with even more impact and credibility because the client has lived the results?

@MeasureTwiceMNY @morganranstrom @jasonfrieds @AyeshaSelden Relying on referrals is difficult for new advisors simply b/c they don't have anyone TO refer them, & can be limiting for larger firms on growth because referrals are more challenging to scale over time as existing client networks are tapped out.

But I wouldn't call 'dangerous'.

@MeasureTwiceMNY @morganranstrom @jasonfrieds @AyeshaSelden There's nothing wrong (or dangerous) with advisors simply serving the people that they've chosen to serve. And others who seek out (and are referred in to) that same service.

Everyone makes their own choices about what to do with the rest of their time.

Manufacturers & distributors naturally have different incentives than advice-providers. Like doctors vs drug companies.

@LateQuotient @lindseyyoung_qw @sambojarski @AdviserCounsel (Not to pick on wirehouses. It's just that as publicly traded companies, their revenue/advisor productivity metrics are public. ;) )

@LateQuotient @lindseyyoung_qw @sambojarski @AdviserCounsel They believe they're capping fees at an above-market "more-than-is-reasonable" rate when in fact they're capping fees at ~1/4th of what the AVERAGE wirehouse advisor generates as an hourly equivalent for their client-facing work. They're THAT far off. :/

@LateQuotient @lindseyyoung_qw @sambojarski @AdviserCounsel And clearly the regulators don't actually want to regulate advisors OUT of business - they're simply trying to protect consumers, as they should - but that is the end result nonetheless b/c they don't actually understand the economics of advisory firms.

@LateQuotient @lindseyyoung_qw @sambojarski @AdviserCounsel Agreed that they don't literally care how much revenue an advisor generates.

But the issue is that they're capping advisor fees at such a below-market rate that it results in an advisory business that doesn't have the revenue to grow and scale.

@LateQuotient @lindseyyoung_qw @sambojarski @AdviserCounsel Certain regulators are suggesting that no advisor should ever earn an hourly rate above $250/hour.

There are 2,000 working hours in a year. That's $500k of revenue/advisor.

AVERAGE wirehouse advisor is >$1M/year.

At least certain regulators don't understand advisor revenue.

@MeasureTwiceMNY The @XYPlanning petitions (https://t.co/dR8Aw1IklP ) were filed in part for this reason - to bring back the requirement that you can't say you're a "financial planner" or give a financial plan unless you're at least an actual (RIA) fiduciary. We'll see how SEC responds?

@MeasureTwiceMNY Notably, there was a version of this back in 2005 - where new regulations actually would have limited brokerage firms from using "financial planner" if they weren't RIA fiduciaries - but it was ultimately vacated by courts (for other reasons) and never came back.

@MeasureTwiceMNY If the "financial planner" label you're using here proved to be popular with investment firms, they'd simply start using it more, and then it would lose the distinction you're implying here. Nothing really to stop them.

@MeasureTwiceMNY The reason why the "only's" labels have gained any traction at all is "fee-ONLY" was a label that was unequivocally inaccurate for commission-based firms. 

Even then, you saw the industry adopt fee-based accounts and diminish distinctiveness of that label.

@MeasureTwiceMNY Perhaps in an ideal world, but in practice the industry will simply start using whatever term is popular. Thus why stockbrokers and insurance agents started getting called "financial advisors" and "financial planners" to begin with.

@RacerBoy17 @Steph_Bogan @HJudeBoudreaux @moneyeducator @NewPlnrRec As you've highlighted, it really is very expensive and challenging for us to hire and train a new advisor all the way from zero to self-perpetuating biz-dev revenue. (And retain them!)

But what Steph is highlighting is that there are other paths to scale up the advisor team.

@RacerBoy17 @Steph_Bogan @HJudeBoudreaux @moneyeducator @NewPlnrRec In essence, firms that are figuring out how to centralize their marketing cost-effectively are bidding up the cost of service advisor talent over firms that rely on new recruits to do the biz-dev. And since most new advisors struggle w/ biz-dev, they're taking the service jobs.

@RacerBoy17 @Steph_Bogan @HJudeBoudreaux @moneyeducator We're seeing the largest influx of hiring demand at @NewPlnrRec we've ever seen in 12+ years now - hiring for 40 positions simultaneously at https://t.co/UDyaIwnkF0 - and it's all for advisors that will do service, no biz-dev, for higher salaries than in the past.
Mortality Credits ‚Äì Why Immediate Annuities Beat Bond Ladders For Retirement Income: https://t.co/eB1SJdt3jP https://t.co/A5K1c2Oc5E

@RacerBoy17 @Steph_Bogan @HJudeBoudreaux @moneyeducator And the increasing number of firms shifting to that approach is what's bidding up the price of young/new talent entering the industry. Training for service is faster, & lower risk for the firm (less attrition/turnover of team who 'don't make it'), so initial salaries are rising.

@RacerBoy17 @Steph_Bogan @HJudeBoudreaux @moneyeducator And the cost savings of being able to ramp that person up more quickly because they're not responsible for business development is what frees up the revenue/resources to be able to create more marketing infrastructure to feed it.

@RacerBoy17 @Steph_Bogan @HJudeBoudreaux @moneyeducator It's not that it's 'easy' to train someone up to manage $400k in revenue. I think the point is just that it's a lot faster (and thus less expensive) to train someone up to manage $400k in revenue the firm generated, than to train them to generate $400k for themselves.

@AdviserCounsel @moneyeducator That's not far off from the traditional RIA benchmarking study. Though that's historically been closer to 35% overhead, 40% advisors, and 25% profits. (More competition for advisors to switch firms and move clients so it drives up the advisor share?)
@moneyeducator Is that actually your model? Billing hourly and aiming for 1,500 billable hours per year?

@moneyeducator Yes but still a different skillset to do the job sufficiently depending on revenue.

You'll pay an advisor who bills $600/hour differently than one who bills at $200/hour. Just as the advisor with 80 millionaires gets paid differently than 150 clients w/ $200k.

@moneyeducator Still have to answer the earlier question #2 - how much revenue are they responsible for?

The advisor who services 150 clients with $200k accounts ($300k of revenue) is compensated very differently than the advisor overseeing 80 clients who are millionaires ($800k of revenue).

@moneyeducator Well, if you don't do a good job, clients say they're not happy with the knowledge/expertise/service received for the fees they pay - even and including hourly fees - and then they don't want to pay, or ask for refund, or don't come back next year for more planning, etc.

@moneyeducator If the advisor is responsible for making sure services are delivered to clients that generate $300k of revenue, doesn't matter much whether the $300k were hourly, subscription, or AUM fees. Firm brought it, advisor has to do the work to support that revenue.
@moneyeducator Amount of revenue responsibility is a much bigger driver than the nature of the revenue.
@moneyeducator Yes absolutely makes sense. That was where I was going (clearly not clearly!) in separating questions #2 and #3. Existing vs new revenue responsibilities very different!

@moneyeducator If they're full on advisors servicing clients as their primary relationship manager, they're responsible for that client revenue. Or at least they should be - if there are no consequences to losing those clients and revenue that may be problematic long term.

@moneyeducator Depends on the scope of their responsibilities. Do they:
1) Support other advisors and their clients, or have their own clients they are primarily responsible for?
2) If #1 is yes, how much revenue are they responsible for? 
3) Are they accountable for bizdev as well?
